content: I think you're jumping too quickly here. That prompt is to verify that you have the authority to do this. Once entered, you are then prompted for whatever primary password you want. The prompt for Windows password does not happen again.
creator: davidsk

content:
This looks like a similar issue that occurred with various senders and Interac notifications:

https://support.mozilla.org/km/questions/1448953#answer-1655641
creator: sfhowes

content: Entries to Saved Passwords can only be added by checking the box in the password prompt dialog - if the authentication method is 'normal password'. If the method is OAuth2, cookies must be accepted in TB Settings for an oauth:// token to be stored in Saved Passwords. But if logins aren't being saved consistently, there could be other issues, such as an external password manager overriding TB.
creator: sfhowes

creator: @next

content: Try with Windows running in safe mode, which will bypass startup apps like Bitdefender that often cause crashes (unless the TB profile folder is excluded from scanning). If there are no crashes in safe mode, either make changes in Bitdefender settings, or remove it and use the built-in Windows Security.
creator: sfhowes

content: I suggest copying them to your Mail\Local Folders folder to verify that you can see the messages. You may then be able to copy to a recognized archive folder.

content:
That begging message isn't personal — EVERYBODY sees it. If it's bothering you go to Settings and the very first thing is a tick-box labelled When "Thunderbird launches, show the Start Page in the message area." Un-tick it.

If Thunderbird did somehow know you'd donated we'd probably have people screaming about having their privacy violated.

content: I can't speak to whatever your patch management is, but a normal update is supported (I just updated a friend's 115 yesterday in just a minute with no problems - although that is no guarantee on updates. I always recommend doing backups prior to major update.)

content: So a manual USER requested upgrade from 115->128 will work but we aren't sure if I download the 128 binary on an existing 115 install will migrate the profile. The initial release of 128 said this would be forthcoming and I've not heard anything since.

content: Yes, it works. It was your term 'patch management' that was unclear. If set to autoupdate, I believe it runs without notice.
creator: davidsk

content: Yes, the addressbook is separate from accounts. There is no need to change to a different profile if a new provider is the only reason. The new account can be added to the existing profile. My experience on this forum is that users sometimes cause more problems when copying profiles. If you do copy the profile, be sure to copy it when thunderbird is not running.
creator: davidsk

content: Kunt u iets specifieker zijn? Hebt u een probleem of wilt u een Word-document met Thunderbird verzenden?
creator: markh2

content: IMAP accounts are downloaded to computer for thunderbird access. So, they are on computer and also on server. If you delete from computer, IMAP's sync feature also removes from server. You can manage this somewhat by not storing content on computer, just headers. This URL may give some help: https://kb.mozillazine.org/IMAP:_advanced_account_configuration
creator: davidsk

content: I brought up ver 91, clicked to write message, clicked F9 to show contact list, highlighted a mailing list, clicked 'add to BCC' and it worked. If this used to work, maybe the addressbook is corrupted? I don't have any suggestions, but maybe others do.

content:
First, select Help/Troubleshooting Info, Printing (bottom of tab), Clear saved print settings, restart TB, see if printer is detected. If that doesn't help, consider if you have add-ons possibly interfering, or maybe there is a broken layout or incorrect hardware acceleration setting (less likely).

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Safe_Mode
creator: sfhowes

content: Saw your post, Scott, when I was logged onto the group for something else. When I went to see what version I was running, Thunderbird, at that very moment, downloaded 128.2.2 and urged me to restart Tbird to install. With a bad feeling in the pit of my stomach I did just that, and then tested send/receive functionality; all is well, it sends and receives as usual. I'm running Win 10 Pro, however, and will probably cling to that version until I'm in my grave. My wife has Win 11 and I don't like it at all!
